content.text:
Permitted principal uses. The following shall be permitted
principal uses in the R-1A Two-Acre Residence District:

Single-family dwelling with only one housekeeping
unit.
Any municipal building or use.
Florist, greenhouses, farms, country estates or nurseries.

Regularly organized public, parochial and private
nonsectarian elementary and secondary schools under the following
conditions:

Any such school shall be permitted only if its
curriculum is approved by the New York State Board of Regents.

The site size shall meet the standards of the New York State Department of Education; however, in no case shall a school be located on a site of less than five acres. Where dormitory facilities are provided, the minimum site shall be 25 acres and the number of beds shall be governed by Subsection C(7) of this section.

No building or part thereof, or any parking
or loading area, shall be located within 100 feet of any street or
lot line.

Lot coverage for all buildings shall not exceed
10% of the entire site.

No new structure shall exceed 2 1/2 stories
and in no event exceed 35 feet in height; additions to existing buildings
may equal the same in height.

Where the lot lines of the subject lot coincide
with those of another lot in residential district, there shall be
planted or installed along the lot lines thereof trees, shrubs and/or
fencing of such type and spacing as shall be required by the Planning
Board to adequately screen all operations on the lot from the view
of the adjoining properties. Generally such screening shall be five
feet in height from the ground level planted three feet on center,
and if composed of plants, shall not be less than three feet in height,
but capable of reaching eight feet in height at maturity.

Lot area and building requirements for principal uses.
Lot area and building requirements for principal uses shall be as
follows:
Minimum lot area: two acres (80,000 square feet).
Minimum lot width: 150 feet.
Minimum lot frontage: 50 feet.

Front yard: The minimum front yard shall be 50 feet
or the prevailing front yard setback, whichever is greater.[Amended 5-8-2007; 8-28-2007]
Minimum rear yard: 50 feet.
Minimum side yard: 25 feet each.[Amended 5-8-2007; 8-28-2007]
(Reserved)[1]

content.footnote:
[1]
Editor’s Note: Former Subsection B(7), regarding the
minimum aggregate width of both side yards, as amended, was repealed
8-24-2010.

content.text:
Minimum building size: 1,200 square feet of living
space of which 960 shall be on the first floor.

Maximum height: 2 1/2 stories and in no event exceed
35 feet.
Maximum coverage: 10%.
No structure shall project outside the sky exposure plane specified at § 280-45R(1).[Added 5-8-2007; amended 8-28-2007]

The maximum interior floor area of a single-family
dwelling shall not exceed 1 1/2 times the maximum lot coverage,
as expressed in square feet.[Added 5-8-2007; amended 8-28-2007]

Permitted accessory uses. Permitted accessory uses
shall be as follows:

Private garages, limited to one garage building per
property, stables, chicken houses, farm buildings and buildings for
the housing of pets; playhouses.[Amended 5-8-2007; 8-28-2007]
Garden houses or greenhouses.

Professional office or studio of a doctor, dentist,
teacher, artist, architect, engineer, musician or lawyer, provided
that the premises are the principal or main residence of such practitioner.

Professional signs, real estate signs relating to
the premises only, announcement signs for public, charitable, educational
and religious institutions. In all cases signs shall conform to the
City of Glen Cove Sign Ordinance (i.e., announcement signs limited
to 16 square feet; others limited to two square feet).[2]

Servants' quarters and guest houses, but not more
than one such building per lot, nor may such buildings be rented or
occupied by others than employees or guests of the principal resident.
Dining facilities for students or conference participants.

Dormitories, so long as the total number of beds does
not exceed the equivalent of eight per acre of site. Where a portion
of publicly owned property is to be used for such a facility, the
computation of density of beds may be based on 30% of the total land
area of the publicly owned property and such where publicly owned
property has been designated by the City of Glen Cove or other governmental
owner as suitable for the computation of coverage requirements, density
of beds may also be based upon 30% of the total land area of the publicly
owned land area as shall have been so designated.

Outdoor recreation facilities for other than one family
dwelling, provided that such facilities are planned as an integral
part of the principal use and all such uses are located a minimum
distance of 100 feet from any street or lot line.

Accessory recreation facilities, subject to the provisions
of § 245-45T and the City of Glen Cove Swimming Pool Ordinance.[3][Amended 5-8-2007; 8-28-2007]

content.footnote:
[3]
Editor's Note: See Ch. 248, Swimming Pools.

content.text:
Lot area and building requirements for accessory uses.
Lot area and building requirements for accessory uses shall be as
follows:

Maximum height: 2 1/2 stories and in no event exceed
35 feet.

Maximum height of garages: one story, and in no event
shall exceed 16 feet to roof peak.[Added 11-27-2001[4]]

content.footnote:
[4]
Editor's Note: This ordinance also renumbered
former Subsection D(2) as D(3).

content.text: Maximum land coverage: 5%.

Maximum land coverage for garages: limited to 750
square feet.[Added 11-27-2001[5]]

content.footnote:
[5]
Editor's Note: This ordinance also renumbered
former Subsection D(3) through D(6) as D(5) through (8), respectively.

content.text: Minimum distance to rear property line: five feet.
Minimum distance to front property line: 85 feet.
Minimum distance to side property line: five feet.[6]

content.footnote:
[6]
Editor's Note: Former Subsection D(8), establishing
the minimum distance to corner side property line, which immediately
followed this subsection, was repealed 5-8-2007; 8-28-2007.

content.text:
Special uses permitted at the discretion of the Planning
Board. Special uses permitted at the discretion of the Planning Board
shall be as follows:

Nursing homes, provided that the Board shall find
that:
Plans provide for adequate fire protection.
The building was erected prior to 1930.
The plot contains at least 15 acres.

The building is located at least 100 feet from
any property line.

Exterior of the building shall not be so structurally
altered as to materially change its residential character.

Any nursing homes existing prior to January
1983 will be conforming uses and shall require an area of only six
acres.

Conversions of single-family residences to multiple-family
use, provided that the Board shall find that:

Such residences are obsolescent and unfitted
for practical use at the time of the application for conversion, are
on plots not less than 10 acres and were erected prior to 1930.

The conversion will not so change the outward
appearance of the building as to call undue attention to the fact
that it is a multiple-family dwelling.

Adequate fire exits and other protection are
provided.

The lot shall be of sufficient size to provide
at least 40,000 square feet per family.

Off-street parking will be provided at the rate
of at least two spaces per dwelling unit.
Changes in noncomplying buildings in conformance with § 280-30 of this chapter.

Public utility installations, buildings and structures,
provided that the same are suitably located and planned as to site,
lot area, height, yards (front, side and rear) and exterior appearance.

Libraries, museums, art galleries, golf clubs, none
of which shall be operated for profit.

Churches and other places of worship, including Sunday
School buildings, parish houses, rectories, provided that:
The plot contains at least two acres.

Plans provide for adequate fire exits and other
protection.

Buildings on subject plot are at least 50 feet
from any property line.

All buildings on subject plot shall not occupy
in excess of 50% of total land area.
Adequate off-street parking is provided.

On-premises parking area shall be adequately
screened from adjacent property owners.

Entrances to premises contain driveway for entering
and separate driveway for exiting.

Scientific and research laboratories, conference facilities;
computer centers used in conjunction with conference facilities; resident
corporate and professional training and administrative facilities;
health spa; institutions for higher learning, including colleges,
universities, junior colleges, seminaries and convents, along with
accompanying service and administration buildings. Uses permitted
under this subsection shall meet the following requirements:

The building being utilized for the primary
use was erected prior to 1930.

The conversion to nonresidential use shall not
materially change the original residential character of the structure.
The site shall be a minimum of 15 acres. Where dormitory facilities are provided, the minimum site shall be 25 acres and the number of beds shall be governed by Subsection C(7);

No structure, principal or accessory, shall
be closer than 200 feet to an adjacent property line.

No structure, principal or accessory, shall
be closer than 100 feet to the right-of-way of a public street.

Land coverage of all structures shall not exceed
4% of the entire site. Where a portion of publicly owned property
is to be used, the computation for coverage may be based upon 30%
of the total land area of the publicly owned site. Where the site
to be used is contiguous to, or surrounded by, publicly owned property,
the computation for coverage may be based upon 30% of the total land
area of the publicly owned site, provided that the City of Glen Cove
or other governmental owner as the case may be shall designate such
publicly owned land area as suitable for computation of coverage requirements.

No new structure shall exceed 2 1/2 stories
and in no event exceed 35 feet in height. Additions to existing buildings
may equal the same in height. The design of additions or new structures
must be consistent with the architecture of the original structure
on the site.

Where the lot lines of the subject lot coincide
with those of another lot in a residential district, there shall be
planted or installed along the lot lines thereof trees, shrubs and/or
fencing of such type and spacing as shall be required by the Planning
Board to adequately screen all operations on the lot from the view
of the adjoining properties. Generally such screening shall be five
feet in height from the ground level, planted three feet on center,
and if composed of plants, shall not be less than three feet in height,
but capable of reaching eight feet in height at maturity.
Parking and loading.
Off-street parking requirements shall be as follows:
Two spaces for each dwelling unit.

One space for each three beds and for each two
members of staff for medical or similar institutions.
One space for each eight club members.

One space for each 300 square feet of professional
office space.

One space for each four seats in a place of
public assembly.

One space for each three employees in nonresidential
uses.

One space for each four trainees or participants
for which a resident conference facility is designed.

One and twenty-five hundredths spaces for each
staff member for an elementary school; 1.25 spaces for each staff
member plus one space for each five seats in the largest assembly
hall for a secondary school; 1.25 spaces for each staff member plus
0.75 space for each student plus one space for each five seats in
the largest assembly hall for a college, university or similar educational
institution.
Off-street loading requirements shall be as follows:

One off-street loading space shall be provided
for each 20,000 square feet or major fraction therefor in a nonresidential
building.
